Title: The second law of infodynamics and its implications for the simulated universe hypothesis
Core Principles or Models: Second Law of Infodynamics; M-E-I Equivalence Principle; Shannon Information Theory
Methodologies Used: Micromagnetic Monte Carlo simulation; SARS-CoV-2 RNA sequence analysis; Information entropy calculation ( $GENIES$  software)
Key Findings or Conclusions: Information entropy in physical systems containing information states remains constant or decreases over time. This supports the simulated universe hypothesis as a built-in data compression mechanism.

Title: COMPASSION, VARIETY AND COHESION FOR METHODS OF TEXT ANALYTICS, WRITING, SEARCH, USER INTERFACES
Core Principles or Models: Homeostatic metrics (Compassion, Variety, Cohesion); Musical rhythmic analysis; Polysemy Disambiguation
Methodologies Used: Computer-implemented system; Rhythmic/tonal analysis; Poetic and metaphoric resonance; Syntactic sentiment parsing; Trigram bridge relevance filtering
Key Findings or Conclusions: Text analytics based on rhythmic patterns is more efficient for sentiment detection than traditional logic. Tracking compassion/tension resolution improves search engine indices and reduces resource consumption.

Title: Challenging Cognitive Load Theory: The Role of Educational Neuroscience and Artificial Intelligence in Redefining Learning Efficacy
Primary Authors: Evgenia Gkintoni, Hera Antonopoulou, Andrew Sortwell, Constantinos Halkiopoulos
Core Principles or Models: Cognitive Load Theory (CLT); Educational Neuroscience (EdNeuro); Machine Learning (CNN, RNN, SVM)
Methodologies Used: Systematic review ( $n = 103$ ); PRISMA guidelines; Risk of Bias assessment (RoB 2 and Newcastle–Ottawa Scale)
Key Findings or Conclusions: AI and ML improve learning efficacy by managing cognitive load and providing personalized instruction based on real-time neurophysiological data (EEG, fNIRS).

Title: The Second Law of Infodynamics: A Thermocontextual Reformulation
Core Principles or Models: Thermocontextual Interpretation (TCI); Second Law of Infodynamics; Minimum Accessibility Principle
Methodologies Used: Theoretical reformulation; Partitioning energy into exergy, entropic energy, and accessibility; Bayesian statistical modeling
Key Findings or Conclusions: The Second Law of Infodynamics describes an agent's tendency to reduce the information gap ( $D_{KL}$  divergence) to increase access to exergy.

Title: Understanding dual process cognition via the minimum description length principle
Primary Authors: Ted Moskovitz, Kevin J Miller, Maneesh Sahani, Matthew M Botvinick
Core Principles or Models: Minimum Description Length Principle (MDL); Kolmogorov Complexity; Dual-Process Theory
Methodologies Used: Minimum Description Length Control (MDL-C); Recurrent Neural Networks with Variational Dropout (VDO); Simulation of Stroop and Two-Step tasks
Key Findings or Conclusions: Dual-process structure enhances adaptive behavior by allowing agents to minimize the description length of their behavior, providing a unified normative explanation for executive control.

Title: Information and Knowledge Diffusion Dynamics in Complex Networks with Independent Spreaders
Primary Authors: Yan Zhuang, Weihua Li, Yang Liu
Core Principles or Models: SEIR Contagion Model with Independent Spreaders
Methodologies Used: Mathematical derivation of critical epidemic thresholds; Simulations on Small World and Scale-Free networks
Key Findings or Conclusions: Independent spreaders facilitate more extensive information diffusion than link contagion alone, particularly in remote or poorly connected network areas.

Title: Dynamic optimisation based fuzzy association rule mining method
Primary Authors: Hui Zheng, He Jing, Guangyan Huang, Yanchun Zhang, Hua Wang
Core Principles or Models: Dynamic Optimisation Based Fuzzy Association Rule Mining (DOFARM)
Methodologies Used: Dual compromise scheme; Smoothly separated partitions; Membership function generation
Key Findings or Conclusions: Resolves sharp boundary problems in serial data and balances multiple performance metrics (accuracy, efficiency, effectiveness) simultaneously.

Title: System 1 and System 2 Thinking
Methodologies Used: Theoretical summary and metacognition analysis
Key Findings or Conclusions: Human thinking is divided into System 1 (automatic, fast, intuitive) and System 2 (slow, logical, effortful). Understanding their interplay helps identify and avoid decision biases.

Title: The synthesis and use of the owl's auditory space map
Primary Authors: T T Takahashi, Avinash Bala, M W Spitzer, David R Euston, C H Keller
Core Principles or Models: Jeffress Model; Topographic map of auditory space
Methodologies Used: Pupillary dilation response (PDR); Binaural analysis of ITD and ILD; Neural cross-correlation; HRTF measurements
Key Findings or Conclusions: Spatial discrimination is explained by changes in the position of the neural image on the auditory space map. Owls determine sound azimuth and elevation via parallel brainstem pathways.

Title: Robust Anomaly Detection in Financial Markets Using LSTM Autoencoders and Generative Adversarial Networks
Methodologies Used: LSTM Autoencoder; Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN); One-Class SVM; Artificial anomaly injection
Key Findings or Conclusions: The hybrid model outperformed classical baselines in detecting point and collective anomalies across diverse asset types and historical regimes like the Global Financial Crisis.

Title: LSTM-Autoencoder for Vibration Anomaly Detection in Vertical Carousel Storage and Retrieval System (VCSRS)
Primary Authors: Jae Seok Do, Akeem Bayo Kareem, Jang-Wook Hur
Core Principles or Models: LSTM-autoencoder; Fisher information matrix (FIM); Effective independence (EFI)
Methodologies Used: Correlation coefficient model; Fast Fourier Transform (FFT); Power Spectral Density (PSD); LSTM-autoencoder training
Key Findings or Conclusions: The combination of the correlation coefficient model and the LSTM-autoencoder achieved an accuracy rate of 97.70% for detecting system anomalies.

Title: Anomaly Detection in Kuwait Construction Market Data Using Autoencoder Neural Networks
Methodologies Used: Deep learning utilizing an autoencoder architecture trained on historical transaction volumes with Adam optimizer and MSE loss
Key Findings or Conclusions: The model successfully detected significant anomalies in land and house transaction volumes, pinpointing spikes correlating with specific market activities.

Title: THE MATHEMATICS OF DIFFUSION
Core Principles or Models: Fick's laws of diffusion; solutions for isotropic and anisotropic media
Methodologies Used: Mathematical derivation; Separation of variables; Laplace transform; Numerical finite-difference methods
Key Findings or Conclusions: Provides a comprehensive collection of mathematical solutions for diffusion processes under various initial and boundary conditions.

Title: Conduction of heat in solids
Primary Authors: Carslaw, H. S.; Jaeger, J. C.
Methodologies Used: Mathematical solutions of heat-flow equations; Operational methods (Laplace transform); Numerical evaluation
Key Findings or Conclusions: Provides a wealth of solutions to heat-flow problems that are directly applicable to diffusion problems due to mathematical analogy.

Title: Cognitive workload estimation using physiological measures: a review
Primary Authors: Debashis Das Chakladar, Partha Pratim Roy
Methodologies Used: Literature review of EEG, fMRI, fNIRS, and eye tracking; Analysis of CNN, LSTM, and GRU techniques
Key Findings or Conclusions: EEG is the most widely used physiological measure for workload estimation; deep learning generally outperforms traditional machine learning in classification accuracy.

Title: The Physics of Electrosensory Worlds
Core Principles or Models: Quasistationary electrodynamics; Dipole fields; Thévenin’s theorem; Ohm’s law
Methodologies Used: Behavioral experiments; Physical simulations; Theoretical modeling
Key Findings or Conclusions: Electric fish use fields for location, navigation, and communication. Detection depends on water conductivity, object permittivity, and discharge properties.

Title: Electroreception, electrogenesis and electric signal evolution
Methodologies Used: Biophysical electrode experiments; Literature Review; Phylogenetics
Key Findings or Conclusions: Synthesizes functional biology and phylogenetic distribution of electroreception; identifies selective forces like sexual selection as drivers of signal diversity.

Title: Gamification in Cognitive Assessment and Cognitive Training for Mild Cognitive Impairment
Methodologies Used: Literature review of clinical studies; Pilot cohorts (Panoramix); Machine learning classification
Key Findings or Conclusions: Serious games can reduce administration time and serve as long-term biomarkers for cognitive decline; avatars help prevent demotivation.

Title: Detection of weak electric fields by sharks, rays, and skates
Primary Authors: Robert K. Adair, Raymond Dean Astumian, James C. Weaver
Core Principles or Models: Self-organization of sensory cells; Voltage-gated proteins
Methodologies Used: Monte Carlo simulation; Quantitative modeling of firing rates; Biophysical analysis of ampullae of Lorenzini
Key Findings or Conclusions: Synchronous firing of sensory cells allows detection of fields as small as 0.5  $\mu V/m$  by elasmobranchs.

Title: Mechanisms of sound localization in the barn owl (Tyto alba)
Core Principles or Models: Jeffress Model; Interaural time and spectral comparisons
Methodologies Used: Search coil technique; Ear occlusion experiments; Ruff feather removal
Key Findings or Conclusions: Barn owls use interaural spectrum for elevation and onset time for azimuth; the facial ruff is critical for elevational localization.

Title: Neural maps of interaural time and intensity differences in the optic tectum of the barn owl
Primary Authors: JF Olsen, EI Knudsen, SD Esterly
Core Principles or Models: Neural mapping of ITD and IID
Methodologies Used: Extracellular single unit recordings; Measuring amplitude and phase spectra in ear canals
Key Findings or Conclusions: Tuning for ITD and IID changes systematically along the optic tectum to create coextensive, independent neurophysiological maps for sound localization.

Title: Auditory Processing, Plasticity, and Learning in the Barn Owl
Primary Authors: José L Peña, William M DeBello
Methodologies Used: Biophysical electrode experiments; in vivo intracellular recordings; Mathematical modeling
Key Findings or Conclusions: The owl brain uses a topographic map of auditory space; neural circuits exhibit adaptive plasticity calibrated by visual input during development.

Title: Creating a sense of auditory space
Methodologies Used: Physiological recordings in mammalian brainstem (MSO); Iontophoresis of strychnine; Computer simulations
Key Findings or Conclusions: While owls use a place map, mammals likely use a rate-code mediated by hemispheric channels to determine sound source location.

Title: Auditory Localization by ITD Analysis - The Jeffress Model
Methodologies Used: Axonal delay lines; Coincidence-detecting neurons
Key Findings or Conclusions: Coincidence detectors and delay lines convert time codes into space codes for sound localization; mechanism confirmed in birds.

Title: Neuromorphic object localization using resistive memories and ultrasonic transducers
Primary Authors: Filippo Moro, Emmanuel Hardy, Bruno Fain, Thomas Dalgaty, Elisa Vianello
Methodologies Used: Piezoelectric micromachined ultrasound transducers (pMUTs); Hybrid memristive-CMOS; Coincidence detectors
Key Findings or Conclusions: Demonstrated an end-to-end sensory processing system inspired by owl neuroanatomy that is significantly more energy-efficient than microcontrollers.

Title: Electrolocation without an electric image
Primary Authors: Gregory M Lewis, Adam J Callanan, John E Lewis
Methodologies Used: Mathematical equations for object localization using instantaneous electric field measures
Key Findings or Conclusions: Shows that object localization is solvable using instantaneous measures of the electric field, linking sensory flow to electrolocation.

Title: Educational Augmented Reality Games
Methodologies Used: Systematic search of literature (Google Scholar, IEEE Xplore); Qualitative and quantitative analysis
Key Findings or Conclusions: AR games are mostly used in natural sciences. Challenge-based learning within constructivism is the most common design principle.

Title: Designing Educational Mobile Augmented Reality Games Using Motivators and Disturbance Factors
Methodologies Used: Qualitative analysis of case studies (Calory Battle AR and Leometry); Questionnaires and interviews ( $n=141$ )
Key Findings or Conclusions: Identified 24 design guidelines across six categories to strengthen motivators and diminish disturbance factors in MAR games.

Title: Explorations in Mixed Reality with Learning and Teaching Frameworks: Lessons from Ludus and the Vulcan Academy
Methodologies Used: Experiential learning scenarios; Randomized control trial ( $n=136$ ); In-class observational study
Key Findings or Conclusions: Mixed reality prolongs student engagement; creative activity within AR is a more powerful tool for learning than passive consumption.

Title: Augmented Reality Games for Health Promotion in Old Age
Methodologies Used: Telephone surveys ( $n=1,013$ ); Paper questionnaires ( $n=551$ )
Key Findings or Conclusions: Older adults are interested in health technology, but barriers like data privacy and usability remain; games must be social and meaningful to be effective.

Title: The Healing App: Augmented Reality and Art for Pediatric Patients with Chronic Pain
Core Principles or Models: Cyborg Manifesto; Moravec Paradox; Site-specific approach
Methodologies Used: Preliminary patient tests monitoring neuro-responses; Collaborative artistic project design
Key Findings or Conclusions: Artistic VR/AR experiences produce a calming effect and have potential to decrease opioid reliance in pediatric chronic pain management.

Title: Enhancing parkinson disease detection through feature based deep learning with autoencoders and neural networks
Core Principles or Models: Feature Based - Deep Neural Network (FB-DNN); Stacked AutoEncoder (SAE)
Methodologies Used: Modified Band Pass Filter; Autoencoder feature extraction; Mel-Spectrogram audio analysis
Key Findings or Conclusions: The proposed FB-DNN model achieved 96.15% accuracy in differentiating Parkinson's disease samples from healthy ones using voice analysis.

Title: Utilizing variable auto encoder-based TDO optimization algorithm for predicting loneliness from electrocardiogram signals
Core Principles or Models: Variable Auto Encoder (VAE); Echo State Network (ESN)
Methodologies Used: Undecimated discrete wavelet transform (UDWT); VAE feature extraction; TDO-optimized ESN
Key Findings or Conclusions: The suggested VAE-OESN system achieved 99.50% accuracy in predicting loneliness from ECG signals, providing a non-invasive screening method.

Title: Automated Evaluation of Text and Discourse with Coh-Metrix
Methodologies Used: Computational tool development; Language and discourse measures
Key Findings or Conclusions: Describes a tool that provides language and discourse measures to coordinate studies of language, corpus analysis, and cognitive science.

Title: Too Much of One Thing, Too Little of Another? Comparing Cohesive Networks Between Humans and ChatGPT in Academic Writings and Translations
Methodologies Used: LASSO regression; Random forest modelling
Key Findings or Conclusions: Human-translated texts overuse additive conjunctions while ChatGPT underuses determiners; both show lower logical coherence than original academic writing.

Title: Circumpolar Gamifications in the Age of Global Warming: Ice Levels, Anxiety and the Anthropocene
Methodologies Used: Historical analysis of Arctic-themed videogames; Geolocation-based AR project case study
Key Findings or Conclusions: Indigenous communities must maintain control over their own 'infomes'; games must shift from colonial tropes toward authentic creation.

Title: Outlier Detection and Quasi-periodicity Optimization Algorithm: Frequency Domain Based Outlier Detection (FOD)
Methodologies Used: Algorithm development (FOD); Simulation under various distributions; Real data applications
Key Findings or Conclusions: The FOD approach detects quasi-periodic outliers in time series data more efficiently and faster than traditional z-score or Grubbs' tests.

Title: Hybrid numerical methods for convection–diffusion problems in arbitrary geometries
Methodologies Used: Hybridization of NI-FEM and NI-FAM; Transverse integration; Rectangular and triangular nodes
Key Findings or Conclusions: Hybrid schemes provide accurate results on coarse meshes for convection-diffusion problems in irregular geometries.

Title: Mass Transfer Kinetics
Methodologies Used: Convection-diffusion equations; Computational fluid dynamics (CFD); Multiscale modeling
Key Findings or Conclusions: Quantifies the rate of species movement across phase boundaries; essential for pollution removal and resource recovery.

Title: The Divine Mathematics, Part 1: The Holy Quran's Articulation of Fuzzy Mathematics
Methodologies Used: Linguistic analysis; Qualitative conceptual resonance mapping
Key Findings or Conclusions: Fuzzy Mathematics offers a framework for handling linguistic ambiguity in the Quran, revealing a worldview aligned with multivalued logic.
